author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korean Propaganda Gets a YouTube Makeover: Fewer Parades, More Pizza
description: YouTube and other social media platforms give the country an easy way to spread propaganda and push a more modern, upbeat message: We’re just like you.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — A well-dressed young woman toured a shiny, brightly lit grocery store in Pyongyang, where high-heeled women browsed shelves and refrigerators filled with beverages, chocolates, candies and other snacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Siegemund and Zvonareva Win U.S. Open Doubles Title
description: After winning, the partners asked if they could hug, given social distancing rules.
content: As the disbelief of winning her first Grand Slam women’s doubles title began to set in Friday afternoon, Laura Siegemund had an important question for the chair umpire, Eva Asderaki-Moore:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Remember Brexit?
description: The drama continues to unfold.
content: Before the coronavirus pandemic, Britain’s tortuous debate on how to exit the European Union — while maintaining all the perks of membership — was a perennial of global news. The long-running political drama went from one “final” Brexit deadline to the next until, at 11 p.m. Coordinated Universal Time on Jan. 31, 2020, Britain left the union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: A Global Health Star Under Fire
description: Former and current employees accuse Dr. Lucica Ditiu, leader of Stop TB, of harassment and bullying. The complaints threaten to slow prevention efforts worldwide.
content: The leader of a global campaign to prevent tuberculosis has been accused of bullying and harassing employees, and creating a poisonous work environment especially for people of color, according to interviews with current and former staff members and internal documents obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our 25 Most Popular Recipes of the Summer
description: Hold on to the season with NYT Cooking’s top recipes.
content: This summer, NYT Cooking’s most popular recipe was Ali Slagle’s ginger-lime chicken (above). Hold on to the season with that dish or any of the other recipes in the collection below, like Yasmin Fahr’s sheet-pan baked feta with broccolini, tomatoes and lemon, Yewande Komolafe’s crispy tofu with cashews and blistered snap peas or Jerrelle Guy’s strawberry spoon cake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priyanka Runwal
title: In This Woodpecker Kingdom, War Is a Spectator Sport
description: When prime habitat is up for grabs, acorn woodpeckers travel from all around to see who will win.
content: Acorn woodpeckers are renowned food hoarders. Every fall they stash as many as thousands of acorns in holes drilled into dead tree stumps in preparation for winter. Guarding these “granary trees” against acorn theft is a fierce, familial affair. But all hell breaks loose when there are deaths in a family and newly vacant spots in prime habitat are up for grabs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekita Rivas
title: How to Transform Your Place for an Intimate Wedding
description: Here are a few tips on how to decorate and bring your wedding vision to life for an at-home wedding.
content: The night before her wedding, Maya Posey-Pierre crouched on the living room floor of her Brooklyn apartment watching YouTube tutorials on floral design. She neatly laid out rows of orange and white roses, which she bought in bulk from Trader Joe’s. Armed with floral shears and sheer determination, she got to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: All the President’s Insecurities
description: Donald Trump is his own whistle-blower.
content: WASHINGTON — During his 2016 bid, Donald Trump would sometimes pause from bashing elites and the media to speak with awe about a phone call he had with a Very Important Journalist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman, Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Inside the Clash Between Powerful Business Leaders and N.Y.C.’s Mayor
description: The tensions burst into the open when 163 executives joined to criticize Bill de Blasio’s leadership. Others think their portrait of the city is overly bleak.
content: With conditions decaying in New York City neighborhoods and business districts, a powerful corporate executive traveled to Gracie Mansion in July to meet with Mayor Bill de Blasio. He briefed the mayor on a plan — prepared by 14 consulting firms — for how City Hall could work with business leaders to overcome the pandemic downturn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Ancient Python Lays Eggs, Apparently Without Male Help
description: The snake, which is about 62 and hasn’t had contact with a male python in at least 15 years, surprised zookeepers at the St. Louis Zoo.
content: It’s been about two months since zookeepers at the St. Louis Zoo found a ball python believed to be about 62 years old coiled around a clutch of seven eggs she had laid. But the surprise has not worn off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2020 U.S. Open: Women’s Final Preview
description: Naomi Osaka and Victoria Azarenka will play in the women’s singles final of the United States Open on Saturday.
content: How to watch: From 4 p.m. to 7 p.m. on ESPN; and streaming on the ESPN app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Toots Hibbert, a Father of Reggae, Is Dead
description: The first to use the word reggae on a record, he sang in a soulful tone and wrote songs with subtle social commentary, helping bring the sounds of Jamaica to the world.
content: Toots Hibbert, one of the fathers of reggae music, whose vocals imbued the genre’s sound with an exhortatory power drawn from American soul, died on Friday night in Kingston, Jamaica. He was believed to be 77.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Loyalists Tried to Influence C.D.C. Virus Reports
description: AstraZeneca’s vaccine trials resume in Britain after a safety review. Michigan State University students are asked to quarantine after an uptick in cases.
content: Political appointees at the Department of Health and Human Services have repeatedly asked the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to revise, delay and even scuttle reports on the coronavirus that they believed were unflattering to President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Peril and Protection in Smoky Air
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 12, 2020.
content: “I told her the sun was blocked by smoke. She turned to me and asked, ‘Is this how the dinosaurs died?’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Flip
description: Ryan McCarty’s puzzle spins us about a bit.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Time will tell if Ryan McCarty becomes one of these mad scientists who crafts puzzles with ever diminishing numbers of clues — there are 60 today, which go with the pinwheel geometry. Chunky grids indicate low word counts, which makes sense (the pithiest ones, which contain as few as 50 words, start to look very similar). The challenge of low word count goes with themeless puzzles, a more subtle “constructor’s” constraint, if you will, and tends to make for a tough solve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: How to Declutter Your Digital World
description: If you’re overwhelmed from telecommuting for months, here are ways to step away from your devices and, just maybe, get to inbox zero.
content: Working remotely may have eliminated your commute and allowed you to spend the day in your pajamas, but it also means you’re most likely bombarded with digital communication every second of the day — from personal and professional emails crowding your inboxes to push notifications reminding you of every news development to the nonstop viral allure of Twitter and Instagram.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: Extinction Is Not Inevitable. These Species Were Saved.
description: Conservation efforts have saved up to 48 mammal and bird species since 1993, but scientists say much more is needed to stem biodiversity loss.
content: The Przewalski’s horse is exceptional. It is the only horse species that has never been domesticated, and it also managed to very narrowly escape a brush with extinction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Marjorie Olster
title: Iran Executes Wrestler Accused of Murder After He Took Part in 2018 Protests
description: Many suspected that the charges against Navid Afkari were false, and international sports groups had mounted a campaign for clemency.
content: Iran said Saturday that it had executed a 27-year-old wrestler accused of murder after he took part in antigovernment protests two years ago, a case that set off a campaign by international sports groups to demand clemency for the athlete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 36 Years Later, Police Arrest Suspect in Rape and Killing of a 14-Year-Old
description: Using DNA evidence, the authorities in Rochester, N.Y., said that they had charged Timothy L. Williams of Melbourne, Fla., with murdering Wendy Jerome on Thanksgiving Day in 1984.
content: The last time Wendy Jerome was seen alive she was leaving her home in Rochester, N.Y., to deliver a birthday card to a friend who lived nearby. It was around 7 p.m. on Thanksgiving and Wendy, who was 14, had to be home by an 8 p.m. curfew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Now It’s Not Safe at Home Either. Wildfires Bring Ashen Air Into the House.
description: Our reporter, a San Francisco resident, describes family life amid a pandemic and a natural disaster.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — The new thing we do here when we get up in the morning, even before the tooth brushing and the coffee making, is to look at the sky. Then we look at the internet to see if our eyes deceive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum and Benjamin Weiser
title: Trump Accuses Judge of ‘Stacking the Deck’ Against Him in Tax Ruling
description: The president is appealing an order that allowed his tax returns and other financial records to be released to the Manhattan district attorney.
content: President Trump’s lawyers on Friday accused a federal judge of “stacking the deck” against Mr. Trump in his long-running fight to block the Manhattan district attorney from getting his tax returns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel C. Dennett
title: Why Are We in the West So Weird? A Theory
description: In his groundbreaking new book, “The WEIRDest People in the World,” the anthropologist Joseph Henrich argues that people from Western countries have a unique psychology.
content: THE WEIRDEST PEOPLE IN THE WORLDHow the West Became Psychologically Peculiar and Particularly ProsperousBy Joseph Henrich
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: More Than 50 Dead After Gold Mines Collapsed in Eastern Congo
description: Heavy rains triggered landslides that fell the mines.
content: KINSHASA, Congo — More than 50 people are dead after landslides caused the collapse of three artisanal gold mines near the city of Kamituga in the Democratic Republic of Congo’s South Kivu province on Friday, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How to Revisit Your First Date
description: Your relationship might be sorely in need of attention. Why not recreate the special day that sparked it, with an enhancement or three?
content: For many people, the monotony of the last 160-plus days has depleted just about everything. You aren’t alone if you barely recognize yourself, let alone your partner and the special qualities that attracted you to him or her in the first place. Stress and worries over health or financial hardship might have increased, and romance and excitement in your daily life may have disappeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo and Hilary Moss
title: Feed a Craving for Eggplants or Italian Film
description: This week, take a quick cooking class, stream ‘Caesar Must Die’ and pull back the curtain on an opera company.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Stanford
title: ‘Nomadland’ Wins Top Prize at the Venice Film Festival
description: The first major international movie event since the coronavirus pandemic began drew to a close and handed out its biggest award.
content: “Nomadland,” a film written and directed by Chloé Zhao, won this year’s Golden Lion, the top prize, at the 77th edition of the Venice Film Festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Naomi Osaka and Victoria Azarenka Get Test of Mettle in U.S. Open Final
description: Osaka has had to manage an injury and the spotlight as one of the game’s biggest stars. Azarenka’s win over Serena Williams in a semifinal showed her renewed confidence.
content: As Naomi Osaka and Victoria Azarenka meet in the United States Open final on Saturday, they share a common thread through Osaka’s current coach, Wim Fissette.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Kevin Dobson, ‘Kojak’ and ‘Knots Landing’ Actor, Dies at 77
description: Starting out by working odd jobs while auditioning, he found his greatest success playing a pair of television detectives.
content: Kevin Dobson, the actor best known for playing a pair of detectives on television — Telly Savalas’s protégé on “Kojak” and Michelle Lee’s love interest on the prime-time soap opera “Knots Landing” — died on Sept. 6 at a hospital in French Camp, Calif. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Terence Conran, Designer and Retail Magnate, Is Dead at 88
description: An entrepreneur of mercurial moods and missionary zeal, he created an empire to market his designs and later opened restaurants in London, Paris and New York.
content: Terence Conran, a London designer and retailing magnate who eased the gloom of postwar British austerity with stylish home furnishings affordable on a teacher’s salary, and then suffered financial reverses before reinventing himself as an international restaurateur and doyen of modern design, died on Saturday at his country home in Berkshire, England. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Astead W. Herndon
title: A Big Florida Poll, Nevada Tightens, Trump on Defense: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: As new polling continues to give clues toward the states in play for the presidential campaign, President Trump was once again at the center of two story lines that consumed the news.
content: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Trump Has Changed the Face America Presents to the World
description: The people who now represent the United States, interacting with visiting foreign leaders in Washington and at the highest levels abroad, are overwhelmingly white and male.
content: WASHINGTON — For two decades, the United States presented an official face to the world that reflected the power and promise of a land of immigrants.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Do We Look Down on the Less Educated?
description: Readers respond to an Op-Ed arguing that the contributions of those without a diploma have been devalued.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Abby Goodnough
title: Political Appointees Meddled in C.D.C.’s ‘Holiest of the Holy’ Health Reports
description: Trump loyalists at the Health and Human Services Department have been exerting influence on the Centers for Disease Control’s weekly reports on all disease outbreaks, the coronavirus and beyond.
content: WASHINGTON — Political appointees at the Department of Health and Human Services have repeatedly asked the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to revise, delay and even scuttle weekly reports on the coronavirus that they believed were unflattering to President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle and Henry Fountain
title: In Oregon, a New Climate Menace: Fires Raging Where They Don’t Usually Burn
description: The northwest part of the state, usually much wetter, has dried out this year, enabling flames driven by powerful winds to “just explode down these canyons.”
content: The blazes that raced across western Oregon this week could be the most unexpected element in a fire season that’s full of surprises: Not just more wildfires, but wildfires in places that don’t usually burn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Simeon Coxe, Whose Silver Apples Presaged Synth-Pop, Dies at 82
description: In the late 1960s, playing a homemade electronic instrument, he created “the mating call between a jackhammer and a Veg-O-Matic.”
content: Simeon Coxe, a songwriter, singer and inventor whose psychedelic-era band Silver Apples was one of the first to put a synthesizer at the center of its music, died on Tuesday at his home in Fairhope, Ala. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilana Kaplan
title: Who Is Paris Hilton, Really?
description: The heiress and proto-influencer says that she spent nearly two decades playing a character. Now she’s ready to be herself.
content: Lounging cross-legged on her bed at home in Beverly Hills and wearing a turquoise hoodie, Paris Hilton appeared at ease. There were none of the affectations that have defined her public image for two decades: the flat baby voice, the tiny, shimmering outfits, the faux ditziness, the stance that everything cool was “hot.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: After a Pandemic Pause, ICE Resumes Deportation Arrests
description: The Trump administration says it is targeting criminals, but government data suggests that many others are getting caught up in immigration sweeps.
content: LOS ANGELES — For Alicia Flores Gonzalez, Aug. 4 began like any other day. She dropped her little girl at day care and drove to work at a winery in the Sonoma Valley. But as she was parking her white Toyota Tacoma, she found herself surrounded by several armed men. “What happened? What did I do?” Ms. Flores recalled asking them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Films Hit Festivals Trying to Create Buzz Without a Crowd
description: The pandemic has upended the circuit, meaning smaller movies face an even greater challenge in attracting deep-pocketed distributors.
content: LOS ANGELES — Some 70 cars crammed into a downtown Los Angeles parking lot surrounded by high rises and a smattering of food trucks on Thursday night to watch “Concrete Cowboy,” a father-son film starring Idris Elba and set in North Philadelphia’s Black cowboy community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
title: Trump Onslaught Against Biden Falls Short of a Breakthrough
description: President Trump has leveled scathing law-and-order attacks on Joseph Biden for weeks. But a new poll shows Mr. Biden ahead in three states Mr. Trump hopes to pick up, and maintaining a lead in Wisconsin.
content: President Trump’s weekslong barrage against Joseph R. Biden Jr. has failed to erase the Democrat’s lead across a set of key swing states, including the crucial battleground of Wisconsin, where Mr. Trump’s law-and-order message has rallied support on the right but has not swayed the majority of voters who dislike him, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times and Siena College.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon prepare us for shorter days and longer nights.
content: ACROSTIC — This is one of those public service announcement acrostic puzzles, which I love because they provide scientific evidence that gives credibility to some (usually) human foible that I’ve always wondered about. The excerpt today is from a book called “The Alchemy of Us: How Humans and Matter Transformed One Another,” by Ainissa Ramirez, that covers eight inventions. Clocks and light bulbs are among them, both disrupters of darkness and sleep, and the excerpt concerns an interesting pre-technology sleeping pattern that I had never known of before but which sounds like part of human nature. Isn’t it curious to consider that all those times you woke up a few hours into sleep, raring to finish a task or get a snack, you might have just been following evolutionary orders?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wildfires Live Updates: Dozens Missing as States Look to Weather for Relief
description: President Trump will visit California on Monday to be briefed about blazes that have burned more than three million acres. Tens of thousands of people have evacuated in Oregon.
content: Dozens of people remain missing in Oregon as wildfires that have torched millions of acres across the West continue to burn on Saturday, the death toll rising to 20 and smoke choking residents in cities far from the fires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Teen Stock Trading Seems Dangerous. It Doesn’t Have to Be.
description: Gunslinging young investors are making stock ownership seem like a terrible idea for novices. But owning equities, with limits and guardrails, can teach kids plenty.
content: This year, Robinhood and its millions of younger-than-average customers have found themselves at the center of attention that is both comic and tragic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: ‘Cuties’ Sparks a Firestorm, Again, After Its Netflix Release
description: Several members of Congress have weighed in on the award-winning film, including to call for its removal from Netflix or a Justice Department investigation.
content: Netflix is facing renewed backlash from subscribers and members of Congress after it released the award-winning French film “Cuties” on its platform this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Rockets’ Danuel House Leaves N.B.A. Bubble After Violation
description: House was said to have had an unauthorized guest in his hotel room at Walt Disney World “over multiple hours” on Tuesday in violation of the league’s health protocols.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — The N.B.A. announced Friday that Danuel House Jr., a reserve forward for the Houston Rockets, had breached the league’s health and safety protocols by inviting an unauthorized guest to his hotel room and that he would be leaving the Walt Disney World campus, where the league has made a major investment to finish out its season inside its so-called bubble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Final Offer
description: I’m going to bet that MaryEllen Uthlaut’s puzzle gets a laugh or two.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is MaryEllen Uthlaut’s third New York Times puzzle, but it’s her Sunday debut and it has been years since those first two grids, so if she was a new name to you then you can sit with me. According to Will Shortz’s print intro, she slipped on a banana peel in the library and caught her balance on a book about puzzles. (Not exactly — she found the book on a random shelf while researching another topic. Still, a funny story for a funny constructor.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere, Noah Weiland and Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Pressed for Plasma Therapy. Officials Worry, Is an Unvetted Vaccine Next?
description: New details of how the president has demanded faster action from health agencies help explain the intensifying concern that he could demand pre-Election Day approval of a vaccine.
content: WASHINGTON — It was the third week of August, the Republican National Convention was days away, and President Trump was impatient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Elaine Yu
title: Families of Hong Kong Activists Arrested at Sea Plead for Access to Lawyers
description: A dozen activists are being held after trying to flee to Taiwan, detentions that echo fears of judicial tactics by mainland China that set off last year’s mass protests in Hong Kong.
content: HONG KONG — The families of a dozen Hong Kong activists arrested at sea last month spoke out for the first time on Saturday, pleading with the Chinese government to allow the detainees access to their chosen lawyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Jonathan Martin
title: Trump and Biden Seek an Electoral Edge From an Unlikely Source: College Football
description: College sports leaders aren’t thrilled to see football assume a role in the presidential campaign, but they’re not surprised.
content: Kevin Warren, the commissioner of the Big Ten Conference, was at his home near Minneapolis one morning this month when President Trump made a hastily arranged call to him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy, Jack Nicas and Mike Baker
title: A Line of Fire South of Portland and a Yearslong Recovery Ahead
description: Firefighters continued to battle blazes along the West Coast that have now charred nearly five million acres. At least 17 people are dead, with dozens still missing.
content: SALEM, Ore. — A 36-mile-wide line of flames edged into the towns around Portland, Ore., and cities along the West Coast were smothered in acrid smoke and ash on Friday as history-making wildfires remained unchecked, killing at least 17 and leaving dozens of people missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Help! Stray Cats Are Taking Over My Block
description: When neighbors start feeding feral cats, you may find your property overrun. Here’s how to deal with it.
content: Q: My neighbor in Westchester County, N.Y., keeps feeding stray cats. One had a litter a few weeks ago. The cats wander into my garden, defecating on my plants and attacking the birds and chipmunks. One of them got into my garage and sprayed. How can I get my neighbor to stop feeding these cats? And how can I get them to stop breeding?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Why Does Trump Want an Inaccurate Census?
description: Congress must extend the deadline for the count.
content: It’s hard to overstate the importance of the census to everyday life in the United States. The vast amount of demographic information it gathers determines who gets how much political power in Congress and the states; it steers more than a trillion dollars in federal funding for health care and other critical services; it guides long-term economic decisions by governments, corporations and mom-and-pop stores; it helps determine the location of highways and schools, hospitals and housing, police and fire stations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David D. Kirkpatrick
title: Bahrain Says It’s Time to Embrace Israel. The Gulf Hears a Saudi Voice.
description: Bahrain’s closeness to Saudi rulers makes it unthinkable the change in diplomatic ties happened without approval. But Saudi Arabia itself may not be in a rush to normalize relations with Israel.
content: The tiny Persian Gulf kingdom of Bahrain lost much of its autonomy nearly a decade ago, when its rulers turned to their neighbor Saudi Arabia to save them from an Arab Spring uprising threatening their power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Colorado Official Sues Postal Service Over Election Mailer She Says Misleads Voters
description: The suit comes as the Postal Service has drawn scrutiny for a mail delivery slowdown that Democrats have charged are part of an effort by President Trump to hobble mail-in voting to bolster his re-election.
content: Colorado’s top election official filed a federal lawsuit on Saturday against the postmaster general and other Postal Service leaders, claiming that a mailer sent to voters in the state was an attempt to disenfranchise them by offering misleading information about how to vote by mail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: As the West Coast Burns, Communities Unravel With Each Death
description: The fires have killed at least 20 people, leaving families and communities devastated up and down the West Coast.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — They lived more than 500 miles from each other — one in the wooded foothills of the Sierra Nevada, northeast of California’s capital, Sacramento, the other in a thickly forested canyon east of Oregon’s capital, Salem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Trump to Visit California After Criticism Over Silence on Wildfires
description: The announcement came after the president acknowledged a wildfire season that so far has claimed at least 20 lives and destroyed millions of acres of land in California, Oregon and Washington.
content: WASHINGTON — After weeks of public silence about the wildfires devastating the West Coast, President Trump scheduled a visit to California on Monday, where he will join local and federal fire and emergency officials for a briefing on the crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: A U.S. Open Missing Fans and Stars: Was It Worth It?
description: No Federer or Nadal, and so many top women taking a pass, plus a fracas with the French, but the United States Tennis Association needed to hold this tournament and has no regrets.
content: Two of the biggest stars in the sport did not make the trip. Another one was disqualified midway through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What Isn’t Trump’s Fault
description: The coronavirus stories that get lost when we focus only on presidential failure.
content: Last weekend, I wrote a column arguing that the blundering of the Trump administration, while real and deadly, may not be responsible for the bulk of America’s coronavirus fatalities. A few days later, courtesy of Bob Woodward’s omniscient tape recorder, we received a reminder of the president’s culpable failures in the pandemic’s early days — which offered ammunition to readers who found my column to be implausible, pro-Trump special pleading or just obtuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Targeting Conservative Terrain, Democrats Look to Independent Challengers in Alaska
description: The bids of two congressional candidates are shaping up as crucial tests of whether a centrist label can overcome resistance to Democrats in a conservative-leaning state.
content: PALMER, Alaska — Reaching into remote territory where they usually have little chance of victory, Democrats are mounting serious efforts to pick up Senate and House conservative-leaning seats here, reflecting rising hopes about their chances of winning control of the Senate and tightening their grip on the House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Confederate Statue Near Site of White Nationalist Rally in Charlottesville Is Removed
description: The 111-year-old monument, “At Ready,” includes two cannons and cannonballs. It was near the site of a violent white supremacist rally in 2017 that killed one and injured dozens more.
content: With yellow bands and rope wrapped around its legs, waist and ankles, a Confederate statue in Charlottesville, Va., the site of a violent white supremacist rally in 2017, was removed on Saturday morning from its pedestal at the Albemarle County courthouse after 111 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Amy Qin
title: Disney Wanted to Make a Splash in China With ‘Mulan.’ It Stumbled Instead.
description: A political controversy over a filming location was a rare blunder for one of the world’s savviest companies in dealing with China.
content: LOS ANGELES — Executives at Walt Disney Studios were celebrating. “Mulan,” a $200 million live-action spectacle five years in the making, had arrived on Disney’s streaming service to strong reviews, with critics lauding its ravishing scenery and thrilling battle sequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: What if Trump Fought the Virus as Hard as He Fought for His Wall?
description: Many thousands of American lives would have been saved.
content: What would America be like today if President Trump had acted decisively in January to tackle the coronavirus, as soon as he was briefed on the danger?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 12, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 12, 2020
content: An article on Thursday about President Trump’s encounters with Black leaders misstated the month George Floyd was killed by the police. It was May, not June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Another Gulf State Recognizes Israel. Here’s Why It Matters.
description: The announcement that Bahrain would establish full diplomatic relations with Israel leaves open the possibility that more Arab states will follow.
content: President Trump made a bit of history on Friday when he announced the Persian Gulf kingdom of Bahrain would establish full diplomatic relations with Israel. Bahrain’s move, a month after the United Arab Emirates normalized relations, brings the number of Arab countries that recognize Israel to four (Egypt did so in 1979, Jordan in 1994), and furthers a strategic realignment of the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Sabrina Tavernise
title: In Wisconsin Poll, Unrest Concerns Don’t Translate Into Surge for Trump
description: Worries about law and order have become so prevalent that likely voters say it’s just as important as solving the coronavirus pandemic. But voters aren’t favoring Mr. Trump on the issue.
content: The key battleground of Wisconsin, which President Trump carried in 2016 by talking up trade, the economy and doubts about Hillary Clinton, is now awash in deep concern about violent crime, riots and protests — but voters aren’t favoring Mr. Trump on those issues even though he is pushing them hard, according to new polling from The New York Times and Siena College.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Gene Budig, Last President of the American League, Dies at 81
description: After a distinguished academic career, he brought his love of baseball to a position that he considered a dream job — but that was eliminated five years later.
content: Gene Budig, the soft-spoken former chancellor of the University of Kansas who in 1994 became the final president of baseball’s American League, died on Tuesday at his home in Charleston, S.C. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Afghanistan Peace Talks Open in Qatar, Seeking End to Decades of War
description: The Afghan government and the Taliban are finally coming to the table, after repeated delays. But the violence continues, and the challenges are vast.
content: DOHA, Qatar — The Taliban and the Afghan government began historic peace talks in Qatar on Saturday, aimed at shaping a power-sharing government that would end decades of war that have consumed Afghanistan and left millions dead and displaced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Don Clark
title: SoftBank Said to Be Near Deal to Sell British Chip Designer Arm
description: A sale to Nvidia for more than $40 billion would net billions of dollars for the Japanese tech investor and create a powerhouse in the semiconductor industry.
content: SoftBank is near a deal to sell the British chip designer Arm to Nvidia, two people briefed on the matter said on Saturday, which would raise billions for the Japanese technology investor and create a powerhouse in the semiconductor industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano
title: Prepare Children to Return to the Classroom
description: Face mask? Check. Hand sanitizer? Got it. Here’s how you can help kids ease back into school this fall.
content: Ever since schools closed last spring, many kids across the country have been excited to get back into the classroom. For some, in-person instruction has already begun — albeit with new precautions: In Vermont, for example, class might take place in the open air, under a tent, while in South Carolina, some students might find their desks separated from their neighbors’ by plexiglass dividers. Elsewhere, cities like New York and Providence, R.I., have delayed the start of the term to better prepare their teachers and facilities for students returning to campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: How China Brought Nearly 200 Million Students Back to School
description: China says the reopening of classrooms proves that its top-down system is superior. To overwhelmed teachers and students stuck on campuses, its restrictions can feel like overkill.
content: Under bright blue skies, nearly 2,000 students gathered this month for the start of school at Hanyang No. 1 High School in Wuhan, the Chinese city where the coronavirus first emerged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: A Young Core Carries the Celtics Past the Raptors. But There’s More Work to Do.
description: Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown and Marcus Smart played like veterans in dethroning the Toronto Raptors.
content: The last time Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown and Marcus Smart were in a Game 7, they were up-and-coming youngsters on a 2018 Boston Celtics team that was full of potential going up against LeBron James and the Cleveland Cavaliers. Tatum even famously dunked on James in the fourth quarter of a losing effort — a small taste of his growth to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Siegel and Josephine Sheng
title: Make a Cube, Then Make a Bigger Cube
description: Using modular origami you can turn newspaper into a cube, then create an intricate mathematical puzzle.
content: Sonobe modules follow the rules of traditional modular origami, beginning with a flat square of paper and then combining pieces into structures without tape or glue. The cube that you can make from this simple start is particularly elegant and appealing. It is the same on all six sides and very stable, and it can be combined to make other structures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: A Secret Recording Reveals Oil Executives’ Private Views on Climate Change
description: At a meeting last year, industry leaders contradicted public claims that emissions of climate-warming methane are under control
content: Last summer, oil and gas-industry groups were lobbying to overturn federal rules on leaks of natural gas, a major contributor to climate change. Their message: The companies had emissions under control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Mandela, Gorbachev, Trump? A Disruptive President Plays Peacemaker
description: President Trump seems exceedingly unlikely to receive a call from the Nobel Committee next month, but all the talk of peace prizes spotlights what has become a core foreign policy message in recent weeks.
content: WASHINGTON — Even before President Trump announced a diplomatic breakthrough between Israel and Bahrain on Friday, he had been nominated twice this week alone for the Nobel Peace Prize. The nominations, each from a right-wing Scandinavian politician, were met around the world with a mixture of amusement and dismissal: Much like submitting art or writing for a prize, such a designation doesn’t mean much in itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Sanders Urging Biden to Do More to Excite Progressives
description: Bernie Sanders has been sounding more direct notes of caution to the Biden campaign, saying the centrist former vice president should work harder to appeal to young voters and Latinos.
content: When Senator Bernie Sanders dropped out of the presidential race in early April, he vowed that the progressive movement he championed would carry on. And while at nearly every turn, he has encouraged his supporters to unite behind Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic nominee, he and others in the party’s left wing have tried to nudge the former vice president more toward the policy goals his movement  supports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: As Both Sides Dig In, What’s the Endgame for Belarus?
description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko seems set on relentless repression, while protesters think peaceful defiance will win in the end.
content: MOSCOW — Viewers of a news show on Belarusian state TV got an unpleasant surprise recently when a disparaging report about protests sweeping their East European nation got the country’s name wrong. It referred to Belarus as Belorussia, a Soviet-era designation that was dropped nearly three decades ago but is still widely used in Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Naomi Osaka, While Rallying for Social Justice, Wins U.S. Open Title
description: “The point is to make people start talking,” said Osaka, who wore masks to the court in each of her seven victories bearing the names of Black people who were victims of violence.
content: Naomi Osaka had just come back to secure her second United States Open singles title. She had tapped rackets with Victoria Azarenka, thanked the chair umpire and consulted with a WTA Tour media official about the commitments to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer, Katie Thomas and Benjamin Mueller
title: AstraZeneca Partly Resumes Coronavirus Vaccine Trial After Halting It for Safety
description: The company said tests of its vaccine would start up again in Britain while remaining suspended in the U.S. and other countries. Pfizer, a competitor, announced an expansion of its trials.
content: The pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca said Saturday that it had resumed its coronavirus vaccine trial in Britain after suspending it six days ago over potential safety issues but that its trials in the United States and other countries were still on hold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Smoke Cloaks Oregon as Wildfires Continue to Spread
description: More than a million acres have burned in the state, destroying entire towns and filling the air with dangerous smoke.
content: More than a million acres have burned in the state, destroying entire towns and filling the air with dangerous smoke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Confederate Statue Removed to Cheers in Charlottesville
description: The “At Ready” monument was removed on Saturday by county workers in Charlottesville, Va. It was located near the site of the white supremacist rally in 2017 that killed one and injured dozens.
content: The “At Ready” monument was removed on Saturday by county workers in Charlottesville, Va. It was located near the site of the white supremacist rally in 2017 that killed one and injured dozens.
source.name: The New York Times
